title: HTML with JavaScript Integration
subject: HTML
theory:
# Integration with JavaScript

JavaScript provides interactivity. It connects to HTML via the `<script>` tag.

## 1. External Script (Best Practice)
```html
<script src="app.js"></script>
```
It is best to place this:
*   At the **end of the body** (`</body>`), OR
*   In the head with the **defer** attribute.

## 2. Internal Script
```html
<script>
  alert('Hello');
</script>
```

## 3. Inline Events (Avoid)
HTML elements have event attributes like `onclick`, `onmouseover`.
```html
<button onclick="doSomething()">Click</button>
```
**Better approach:** Select the element in JS and add an event listener.

## The `<noscript>` Tag
Defines content to be displayed if the user has disabled JavaScript.

```html
<noscript>Please enable JavaScript to use this site.</noscript>
```

## Manipulation (DOM)
JavaScript sees HTML as a tree of objects (DOM). It can change content (`innerHTML`), styles (`style`), and attributes.

common_mistakes.correction: Blocks rendering. Move to bottom or use defer.
Writing complex JS inside onclick="..." is unmaintainable.

interview_questions.question: Where should you put script tags?
interview_questions.answer: Ideally at the bottom of the <body> element or in the <head> using the 'defer' attribute. This ensures the HTML content loads before the heavy script execution begins.

interview_questions.question: What is <noscript>?
interview_questions.answer: It provides fallback content for users who have disabled JavaScript in their browser.

practice_problems.problem: Create a button that changes its text to 'Clicked' when clicked, using internal JS.

real_world_use_cases.description: React/Vue apps usually consist of a single HTML file with one <div id="root"> and a <script> bundle that generates the entire UI.

summary: JavaScript brings HTML to life. The <script> tag allows you to execute logic that manipulates the HTML DOM. Using 'defer' and avoiding inline event handlers ensures your site remains fast and maintainable.
